723514f-a.text:
152-154, 160 Thompson Street, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of Houston Street, a scene in the middle of one of New York's most
important Italian colonies.
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
723514f-a.folder: Thompson Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY

724505f-a.text:
94, 96, 100-102, 104, 106 West Houston Street, north side, adjoining
and at the N.E. corner of Thompson Street.
February 20, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
724505f-a.folder: Houston Street (West & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

724506f-a.text:
Houston Street, west from and including No. 102 West, north side, east of Thompson Street. In the background is seen the western end of this section of West Houston Street, which is the original Houston Street. At its western end Bedford Street begins and runs nearly north, and the second section (originally Hammersley Street) of West Houston Street, which is parallel to King Street, bears off
towards the west.
The subway under Houston Street has now been covered over, but is not
finished at the time of this picture.
February 20, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
724506f-a.folder: Houston Street (West & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

724507f-a.text:
108 to 112, 116, 120 West Houston Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Thompson Street, seen from the S.E. corner just after the demolition of the buildings along the south side of Houston Street. At the right the west side of Thompson Street, looking
north towards Bleecker Street, may be seen.
December 22, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
724507f-a.folder: Houston Street (West & Thompson Street, Manhattan, NY

723515f-a.text:
(1)
Thompson Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Houston
Street, and south to 137 Thomoson Street.
July 18, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, nearly three years later, south only to 147 Thompson Street, the two-story day nursery adjoining the back door of the Church of St. Anthony of Padua (Roman Catholic). 129 West Houston Street or 162 Thompson, the corner building, and 158 Thompson Street adjoining, were demolished late in 1929
(see Houston Street).
February 20, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
A fire of November 4, 1938, in the Rectory shown (No. 151)
caused the death of two individuals.
